She revisited the outfitter, 
choosing the same salesman. 
She approached him with a smile, saying 
'It's me again,' while holding up her pants. 
He smiled and replied, 
'I suppose you'd like to try them on,' before retrieving the key. 
Although the pants were costly, 
they were discounted by half. 
She purchased them and exited the store, 
where her trusted hiking partner, 
Gaada Bait, was waiting. 
She felt uneasy, 
realizing 
she had made a fuss over the hiking pants 
while Gaada Bait lacked a baselayer. 
Despite financial constraints, 
she proposed finding a baselayer for him. 
They re-entered the store 
and found a pair of Outdoor Research pants 
on sale. 
She made a silent prayer 
before proceeding to pay. 
While standing in line, 
she noticed a hiker box 
with a multi-colored fleece on top. 
She shrieked with excitement 
upon seeing it was her size. 
She attempted to pay for the leggings 
but was informed by the cashier that they had already been paid for. 
She and Gaada Bait left crying. 
Gaada Bait never gets trail magic, 
and She-Ra always receives a lot. 
She happily said, 
'Let's go to the other store 
and find you a top.' 
They proceeded down the street 
when a truck honked and stopped 
in front of them. 
It was the couple 
who paid for GB's baselayer bottoms. 
They got out and told GB not to quit 
and to keep going, 
handing him a $100 bill 
and an almost full carton of cigarettes. 
Gaada Bait started crying; 
the couple started crying; 
She-Ra started crying. 
They left,
 telling GB that if he ever needed anything,
to let them know. 
We continued to the next store, 
where we found him a nice top. 
Then, with a smile and a tear in his eye, 
he said, 
'Let's go to McDonald's. 
It's my turn; 
I'm buying.' 
We can dox them, 
picket them, 
or we can keep coming back 
with love and a smile 
and watch the magic unfold. 
One heart at a time.

So I was sitting around reminiscing, as I often do these days, thinking about hiking and trekking the Appalachians. I recalled a hike along the Appalachian Trail across Carver's Gap on Roan Mountain on the Tennessee - North Carolina border back in the late 80s. It was one of many tune-up hikes Geanne and I took in preparation for a more strenuous trek in the Andes Mountains later that next year. Back then there was no one on the trail. The day was clear and sunny as I recall, but cold and windy as...well, you know. Nary a sole did we meet that day, and we spent a good while at Grassy Ridge Bald, a sun-drenched, grassy summit that tops out at over 6100 feet, offering extraordinary views into both states. Well, a couple of years ago in the late fall the experience was quite different  There were people everywhere - wall to wall. Cars were parked up and down the highway, dogs on leashes, hikers of all ages with their ski poles, designer backpacks and Ray-Bans. I thought I was at Dollywood for a second. It was good to see folks of all kinds enjoying a beautiful walk along the AT on such a crisp afternoon. The temperature was a balmy 35¬∞. I just marveled at the looks on all their faces as my mind recalled my own experiences when I wore a younger man's clothes. I felt my time was passing like a hand waving from a train. There are a few moments in your life when you are truly and completely happy, and you remember to give thanks. Even as it happens you are nostalgic for the moment, you are tucking it away in your scrapbook. Nostalgia is a necessary thing, I believe, and a way for all of us to find peace in that which we have accomplished, or even failed to accomplish. John Muir said, ‚ÄúKeep close to Nature‚Äôs heart and break clear away once in awhile, and climb a mountain or spend a week in the woods. Wash your spirit clean. Everybody needs beauty as well as bread, places to play in and pray in, where nature may heal and give strength to body and soul. When one tugs at a single thing in nature, he finds it attached to the rest of the world. Of all the paths you take in life, make sure a few of them are dirt.‚Äù Enjoy these crisp sunny Spring days. Go outside.

Are you visiting the Central District of Shenandoah National Park this weekend?

As first-time angels of any ilk, we‚Äôre excited to announce that we‚Äôll be hosting a pop-up event on Sunday, August 3, 2025! Join us bright and early at 6 AM as we fill the forest with the delicious aroma of bacon. We‚Äôll keep serving until either the food runs out, my knees give out, or 2 PM‚Äîwhichever comes first!

We‚Äôre offering a simple yet delightful menu featuring mostly homemade dishes: casseroles, plenty of eggs, potatoes, fresh fruit, French toast, authentic corned beef hash, pancakes, and burgers (including vegan options). Other offeringswill ensure you leave with a renewed sense of flavor.

If you head south from Bearfence Rock Shelter for about 0.9 miles, you‚Äôll find us at a picnic area just a 2-minute walk from the main trail, where the bacon will beckon you to our canopy.

**Important updates!** After some thoughtful feedback and discussions with our team, I want to clarify a few things: First and foremost, come hungry! We can‚Äôt wait to share our passion for cooking with you in this beautiful park setting. Secondly, feel free to leave your contact info; our expert nurses will gladly perform a non-invasive forehead instant temperature check, which may provide useful information for you. We hope our comfort food will help you feel comfortable discussing any concerns about nagging foot issues, non-healing wounds, or general wellness. Our goal aligns with yours: to keep you on the trail and provide support!

Wash stations and restrooms are available.

There will be a dog with us‚Äîher name is Kyleigh. The best way to win her over is simply to ignore her! Please remember not to feed any animals in SNP, including Kyleigh.

By the way, our hostel and infirmary is located about 2-3 days‚Äô hike south of Rockfish Gap.

Check us out at www.BleesRockfishRetreat.com for more information and feel free to grab some business cards to share with friends and neighbors.

Looking forward to meeting you!

Hello friends! Last year my friends & I started our maiden voyage to section hiking and we finished about 45miles in GA. One of the best things was having a night at a hostel. I think we had the best showers & the best crappy pizza of our lives! Being that we were new to section hiking, of course, we carried way too much weight! The owner of the hostel we stayed at is an avid hiker so he gave us some "real world" advice for cutting down our weight. He even made us a full hot breakfast and dropped us back at the trail. I don't think we appreciated a lodging experience ever before that we were so grateful for!

Since then my husband & I opened our first airb&b in Hiawassee, GA! I wanted to offer it up here for anyone entering or exiting the trails here in Towns County. We're open all year!

$150 per night includes 2 people. Add $50 per night per person for up to 4 total (1 king bed, 2 twin beds) including shuttle service to & from the trail and into town for refilling. Washer & dryer (& loaner pajamas) are on site & we'll come in to fix breakfast each morning!

Let us know if you're interested!

Hiked up Chadwell Gap to Hensley Settlement then settled into a long rumbling course out the ridge trail to nab Sand Cave and White Rocks all in the same day. Very difficult long mileage day with the heat but cooler days are finally coming! I counted nine yellow jacket nests along the trail and almost all of them had been raided by some sort of animal. Most people assume bears but a lot of times the culprit is a skunk.

Take plenty of water if you tackle this one. The only fill up is the pump at Hensley Settlement. Even the falls at Sand Cave are bone dry.
